title: Road and Traffic Signs: Read the Road Like a Pro
summary: Learn the shapes, colours, and layouts of UK road signs so you can respond quickly and confidently.

sections.title: Why Sign Literacy Matters
sections.body: Road signs give you advance notice of hazards, priorities, and legal requirements. Recognising them instantly leaves more time to plan a safe response.

sections.title: Sign Shapes and Colours
items: Circular signs give orders: blue circles are positive instructions, red circles are prohibitions.
Triangles warn of hazards—think ‘A’ for warning.
Rectangles provide information; on motorways they are blue, on primary routes green, and on tourist routes brown.

sections.title: Priority and Warning Signs
items: Give way and stop signs: stop is the only octagonal sign—obey even if the road looks clear.
Priority over oncoming vehicles vs. give priority: note the arrow colours to know who must wait.
Warning signs for bends, junctions, or steep hills tell you to adjust speed and gear early.

sections.title: Variable and Smart Signs
sections.body: Matrix signs on smart motorways and major A roads can display temporary limits, lane closures, or hazard warnings. Treat them as legally enforceable and adjust immediately.

sections.title: Road Markings
items: Double white lines: do not cross or straddle unless it’s safe and legal (e.g., to pass a stationary vehicle).
Yellow box junctions: keep clear unless your exit road is clear.
Cycle lanes and bus lanes: check operation times and solid vs. broken lines before entering.

checklist.label: I can identify sign meaning from its shape and colour alone.
I understand give way, stop, and priority markers and act on them early.
I react quickly to temporary limits and red X signals on smart roads.
I know what road markings mean, including bus lanes and yellow boxes.

practiceTips.label: Flashcard sprint
practiceTips.detail: Use DVSA sign flashcards or apps. Shuffle five at a time and explain the action aloud.

practiceTips.label: Theo’s sign walk
practiceTips.detail: Go for a ten-minute walk and photograph signs (where safe). Back home, describe what each means and what action you’d take.

practiceTips.label: Markings map
practiceTips.detail: Print a blank map of your town and highlight where you’ve seen priority signs, bus lanes, or complex markings. Revisiting spots cements knowledge.

questions.prompt: What does a red circular sign with a white horizontal bar mean?

options.label: No stopping
options.explanation: No stopping signs use blue backgrounds with red borders.

options.label: No entry
options.explanation: The ‘No entry’ sign bans all traffic from entering—obey it every time.

options.label: National speed limit applies
options.explanation: National limit signs are white with a diagonal black stripe.

options.label: Give way
options.explanation: Give way signs are upside-down red triangles with a white centre.

questions.prompt: How should you respond to a rectangular blue sign with a white ‘P’?

options.label: Expect a pedestrian crossing
options.explanation: Pedestrian crossing signs are triangular or rectangular with different symbols.

options.label: Parking is available ahead
options.explanation: Information signs like parking use rectangular shapes and blue backgrounds.

options.label: No waiting at any time
options.explanation: No waiting is indicated by a blue circle with a red border and diagonal line.

options.label: End of controlled parking zone
options.explanation: Controlled zone signs show times and restrictions; a lone ‘P’ indicates available parking.

questions.prompt: What does a red triangle showing a car and skid marks warn you about?

options.label: Loose chippings
options.explanation: Loose chippings are shown with stones flying from tyres.

options.label: Slippery road ahead
options.explanation: Slow down, avoid harsh braking, and choose a higher gear if needed.

options.label: No motor vehicles
options.explanation: ‘No motor vehicles’ is a red circle with a car and motorbike.

options.label: Steep hill ahead
options.explanation: Steep hills are shown by a vehicle on a gradient with a percentage figure.

questions.prompt: A yellow box junction is ahead. What must you do?

options.label: Enter and wait if the lights are green
options.explanation: You must not enter unless your exit is clear—green lights don’t override this.

options.label: Stop before the box unless turning right and only if you can clear it
options.explanation: Keep the box clear to avoid blocking cross traffic.

options.label: Sound the horn before entering
options.explanation: There’s no need to use the horn unless warning of immediate danger.

options.label: Enter if there’s space on the left side only
options.explanation: You must keep the entire junction clear unless turning right and the exit is blocked by oncoming traffic.

questions.prompt: What does a circular blue sign with a white arrow pointing left mean?

options.label: Turn left ahead mandatory
options.explanation: Blue circles give mandatory instructions—this one tells you to keep or turn left.

options.label: Give way to traffic from the left
options.explanation: Give way signs are red and white triangles, not blue circles.

options.label: Left turn prohibited
options.explanation: A prohibition would be a red circle with a diagonal bar over a left arrow.

options.label: Diversion route starts
options.explanation: Diversions usually use yellow signs with black arrows, not blue circular instructions.
